docs.lead_paragraph: Grassroots liberal activists have begun a fund-raising drive to support House members who pledge to vote against any health care legislation that lacks a public insurance option. Read more in the Prescriptions Blog.

headline.main: A Fund-Raiser for the Public Option

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislators in both the House and the Senate are considering creation of a national insurance exchange. But what is that, exactly, and how would it work? Jacob Hacker is a professor of political science at Yale University and a proponent of this idea. He spoke with freelance writer Anne Underwood.

headline.main: A Health Insurance Exchange: The Fine Print

docs.abstract: What is a health insurance exchange, and how would it work? One expert's view.
docs.snippet: What is a health insurance exchange, and how would it work? One expert's view.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a follow-up to today's special section on continuing education, we are answering reader questions about financing their training and choosing a new career. Here is the first installment of answers; submit your own questions here.

headline.main: Answering Your Questions About Continuing Education

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard and Catherine Rampell answer readers' questions about financing their continuing educations, and how to find programs that put them on a good career path.
docs.snippet: Tara Siegel Bernard and Catherine Rampell answer readers' questions about financing their continuing educations, and how to find programs that put them on a good career path.

byline.original: By CATHERINE RAMPELL  and TARA SIEGEL BERNARD

docs.lead_paragraph: Washington will be watching as the results from Afghanistan's 34-way presidential race filter in this morning. Already, the contest is proving tighter than expected, reports The Times's Carlotta Gall. Americans and allied forces hope a successful vote today will indicate increased stability in the region where the Obama administration has injected thousands more troops this year.

headline.main: Early Word: Afghans Go to the Polls

docs.abstract: Afghanistan holds elections, in an atmosphere of violence.
docs.snippet: Afghanistan holds elections, in an atmosphere of violence.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York Times op-ed contributor today diagnoses why insurance policies and claims statements are so hard to parse. They are written at a graduate-school reading level. (Anyone who ever sat in a graduate seminar on Claude Lévi-Strauss can relate.)
docs.abstract: In today's Times, an op-ed contributor on insurance jargon.
docs.snippet: In today's Times, an op-ed contributor on insurance jargon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even before the last wisps of bipartisanship were evaporating from the health care debate, Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, had made clear he opposed President Obama's overhaul effort. It was Mr. DeMint who declared last month, "If we're able to stop Obama on this, it will be his Waterloo."

headline.main: DeMint: On the Road to Waterloo

docs.abstract: A critic of the health care overhaul takes to the road (and airwaves, and Internet).
docs.snippet: A critic of the health care overhaul takes to the road (and airwaves, and Internet).

docs.lead_paragraph: I have survived over 40 years of ill health. Even so I have learned to live a life of chronic patienthood where I am not dominated by illness. I have managed to focus on goals that have nothing to do with illness. Living life for me is learning to surf above the uneven terrain of my health.
docs.abstract: Brian Nelson has lived with health problems most of his life, but recently has coped with dramatic physical changes in his appearance as a result of cancer treatment.
docs.snippet: Brian Nelson has lived with health problems most of his life, but recently has coped with dramatic physical changes in his appearance as a result of cancer treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: End-of-life-care discussions enter the health care debate, but the truth is most doctors and patients aren’t having these conversations.
